The seminar will focus on the literary representation of the most pressing issue at the heart of Israel’s existence -- the diverging attitudes toward the concepts of peace and war, or to conflict-resolution through the exercise of violence more generally. The corpus will include major works in Israeli literature – mostly fiction but some film and poetry as well – from its inception in pre-state Palestine to the present. Issues to be raised: Do literary representations reflect historical realities or do they constructthem? What role do sex/gender differences play in shaping the division between pacifists and their opponents? How does trauma – both personal and collective, past and present – impact the adherence to one position or another? What psycho-political circumstances have determined the glorification of military heroism and its decline? Finally, what does religion have to do with all this? Readings include: prose by S. Y. Agnon, S. Yizhar, Moshe Shamir, Shulamit Hareven, G. Shoham, A.B Yehoshua, Amos Oz, David Grossman, Ron Leshem; poetry by Yitzhak Lamdan, Haim Guri, Yehuda Amichai, Daliah Rvikovitch, Meir Wieselteir, Yizhak Laor; films on Lebanon War; critical studies related to the issues listed above.
